section.title: Second Conditional
section.sectiontitle: Use the Second Conditional to talk about an unreal/imaginary/hypothetical situation and its consequences if + Past Simple + would('d)/wouldn't.
section.text1: The if clause can come first or second in the sentence. If it is first, there is a comma before the result clause.
section.text1a: If I had a car, I would drive to work.
section.text2a: She would change her mind if she knew we were here.
section.sectiontitle2: Apart from would, you can also use could and might in the result clause.
section.text3a: If I had a change of heart, I might forgive him.
section.text4a: I'd live in Jamaica if I could live anywhere.

section.title: First vs Second Conditional
section.sectiontitle: Use the First Conditional to talk about possible/real situations. The form is if + Present Simple + will('ll)/won't. The Second Conditional is for imaginary situations. The form is if + Past Simple + would.
section.text1a: If I go to France, I will visit the Louvre.
section.text2a: If I went to the moon, I would take lots of photos.
section.sectiontitle2: When the subject is I and the verb is to be, we can say If I was or If I were.
section.text3a: If I were you, I wouldn't wear that dress again!
section.text4a: If I was younger, I'd learn to ski.
